Name: Helium
Appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a gray, cloudy glow (or reddish-orange if an especially high voltage is used) when placed in an electric field

Name: Carbon
Category: Reactive nonmetal, sometimes considered a metalloid

Name: Oxygen
Appearance: gas: colorlessliquid and solid: pale blue

Name: Fluorine
Appearance: gas: very pale yellowliquid: bright yellowsolid: alpha is opaque, beta is transparent

Name: Neon
Appearance: colorless gas exhibiting an orange-red glow when placed in an electric field

Name: Aluminium
Category: Post-transition metal, [2][a] sometimes considered a metalloid

Name: Phosphorus
Appearance: Colourless, waxy white, yellow, scarlet, red, violet, black

Name: Argon
Appearance: colorless gas exhibiting a lilac/violet glow when placed in an electric field

Name: Calcium
Appearance: dull gray, silver; with a pale yellow tint[1]

Name: Iron
Appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge

Name: Nickel
Appearance: lustrous, metallic, and silver with a gold tinge

Name: Zinc
Category: Post-transition metal, alternatively considered a transition metal

Name: Selenium
Appearance: black, red, and gray (not pictured) allotropes
Category: Reactive nonmetal, sometimes considered a metalloid

Name: Krypton
Appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a whitish glow in an electric field

Name: Strontium
Appearance: silvery white metallic; with a pale yellow tint[1]

Name: Cadmium
Category: Post-transition metal, alternatively considered a transition metal

Name: Iodine
Appearance: lustrous metallic gray, violet as a gas

Name: Xenon
Appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a blue glow when placed in an electric field

Name: Barium
Appearance: silvery gray; with a pale yellow tint[1]

Name: Lanthanum
Category: Lanthanide, sometimes considered a transition metal

Name: Europium
Appearance: silvery white, with a pale yellow tint;[1] but rarely seen without oxide discoloration

Name: Ytterbium
Appearance: silvery white; with a pale yellow tint[1]

Name: Lutetium
Category: Lanthanide, sometimes considered a transition metal

Name: Mercury
Category: Post-transition metal, alternatively considered a transition metal

Name: Polonium
Category: Post-transition metal, but this status is disputed

Name: Astatine
Category: Post-transition metal, sometimes classified as a nonmetal, a metalloid, or a metal[1][2]

Name: Actinium
Appearance: silvery-white, glowing with an eerie blue light;[1] sometimes with a golden cast[2]
Category: Actinide, sometimes considered a transition metal

Name: Uranium
Appearance: silvery gray metallic; corrodes to a spalling black oxide coat in air

Name: Plutonium
Appearance: silvery white, tarnishing to dark gray in air

Name: Curium
Appearance: silvery metallic, glows purple in the dark

Name: Einsteinium
Appearance: silvery; glows blue in the dark

Name: Lawrencium
Category: Actinide, sometimes considered a transition metal

Name: Meitnerium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a transition metal[3][4]

Name: Darmstadtium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a transition metal

Name: Roentgenium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a transition metal

Name: Copernicium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, alternatively considered a transition metal; may have similarities with the noble gases[1]

Name: Nihonium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a post-transition metal; possibly a metalloid[1]

Name: Flerovium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a post-transition metal; possibly a metalloid[2]

Name: Moscovium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a post-transition metal

Name: Livermorium
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a post-transition metal

Name: Tennessine
Category: Unknown chemical properties, but probably a post-transition metal[3][4]

Name: Oganesson
Category: Unknown chemical properties, was expected to be a noble gas; now predicted to be metallic-looking reactive solid, and either a semiconductor (possibly a metalloid) or a post-transition metal[2][3]
